DEXMEDETOMIDINE

  • Indications and doses
  • Pregnancy
  • Hepatic impairment
  • Contra indications
  • Side effects
  • Administration
  • Important safety information
  • Cautions
  • Monitoring requirements
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Maintenance of sedation during intensive care,

By intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    0.7 microgram/kg/hour, adjusted according to response; usual dose 0.2–1.4 micrograms/kg/hour.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Manufacturer advises avoid unless potential benefit outweighs risk—toxicity in animal studies.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Dose reduction may be required.

Manufacturer advises caution.

Contra indications

  • Acute cerebrovascular disorders
  • second- or third-degree AV block (unless pacemaker fitted)
  • uncontrolled hypotension

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Agitation, blood pressure changes, bradycardia, changes in blood sugar, dry mouth, hyperthermia, myocardial infarction, myocardial ischaemia, nausea, tachycardia, vomiting,

uncommon: Abdominal distension, AV block, decreased cardiac output, dyspnoea, hallucination, hypoalbuminaemia, metabolic acidosis, thirst,

Directions for administration

To be diluted before use.

Important safety information

Dexmedetomidine should only be administered by, or under the direct supervision of, personnel experienced in its use, with adequate training in anaesthesia and airway management.

Cautions regarding administration

  • Abrupt withdrawal after prolonged use
  • bradycardia
  • ischaemic heart disease
  • malignant hyperthermia
  • severe cerebrovascular disease (especially at higher doses)
  • severe neurological disorders
  • spinal cord injury

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

Monitor cardiac function.

Monitor respiratory function in non-intubated patients.

Prepared medicinal forms of DEXMEDETOMIDINE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Solution for infusion
